DOCNAME: CASE OF YORDANOVA AND OTHERS v. BULGARIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Peaceful enjoyment of possessions)
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE and DATE respectively . The first and third applicants live in GPE .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicants’ fathers owned printing houses in GPE , which were nationalised by the NORP authorities in DATE and DATE . After that their assets were taken over by a ORG - owned printing house . In DATE the latter was registered as a ORG - owned company , currently named ‘ PERSON i nauka’ ORG . The company is managed by the Minister of Education . Among the tasks of the company is the printing of school textbooks .
CARDINAL . In DATE ORG adopted ORG ( hereinafter “ LAW ” – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . In DATE the first and second applicants and their mother applied under LAW to receive compensation for the nationalised printing house . As to the manner of compensation , they expressed preference to receive shares in ‘ LAW . In a decision of DATE the Minister of ORG allowed their request , stating that the exact number of shares to be awarded would be determined after a valuation of the assets of the former printing house .

CARDINAL . NORP Despite that , in another decision dated DATE the Minister rejected the request for compensation . That decision was quashed by ORG in a final judgment of DATE , on the ground that it impermissibly modified the previous one , which had become final .

CARDINAL . After that an expert prepared a valuation of the nationalised property , which was confirmed by the Minister of ORG on DATE . CARDINAL . NORP However , on DATE the Minister adopted another decision , stating that the applicants and their mother were to receive compensation bonds instead of shares . He relied in particular on the fact that ‘ PERSON i nauka’ ORG had been included in the list under LAW of the concluding provisions of the Privatisation and Post - Privatisation Control Act DATE ( hereinafter “ the LAW ” – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Once again , that decision was quashed by ORG , in a final judgment of DATE , as it impermissibly modified the previous decisions awarding the first and second applicants and their mother compensation in the form of shares , which had become final . The domestic court held in particular that LAW of the concluding provisions mentioned above could not justify such a modification .

CARDINAL . The first and second applicants’ mother passed away in DATE and was succeeded by them .

CARDINAL . In DATE the third applicant , her mother and her sister applied under LAW to receive compensation for the nationalised printing house . They stated that they preferred to receive shares in ‘ LAW .
CARDINAL . Their request was allowed by the Minister of ORG in a decision of CARDINAL DATE .

Despite the above developments , in another decision dated CARDINAL DATE the Minister stated that the third applicant , her mother and her sister were to receive compensation bonds instead of shares . CARDINAL . The third applicant ’s mother and sister passed away in DATE and DATE respectively , leaving the third applicant her father ’s only surviving heir .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG requested ORG to authorise the transfer to private parties of shares in ‘ PERSON i nauka’ ORG . The authorisation , related to the claims of all applicants , was given on DATE .
CARDINAL . The Ministry took no further measures to complete the compensation procedures .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the third applicant wrote a letter to the executive director of ‘ PERSON i nauka’ ORG , urging him to enter into the company register her shareholding and to present to her copies of all decisions taken by the company ’s general meeting after DATE . She received no response .

CARDINAL . NORP In a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG authorised the sale by ‘ PERSON i nauka’ ORG of real properties owned by the company ( such an authorisation was required by law ) . The applicants applied for the judicial review of that decision , arguing that it affected their rights as shareholders . In a judgment of DATE ORG dismissed their application , noting that they were not shareholders in the company , since the compensation procedures had not been completed with the actual transfer of shares to them in accordance with the law .
